Award.AwardTitle: Recent Developments on Mathematical/Statistical Approaches in Data Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
A workshop on Recent Developments on Mathematical/Statistical Approaches in Data Science will be held at the University of Texas, Dallas, in the Spring of 2019. The workshop will bring together researchers from different disciplines including computational and applied mathematics, statistics, computer science, and engineering to report on cutting-edge methodologies and state-of-the-art computational algorithms in data science. The workshop will provide an opportunity to all the participants to submit their related works to a special issue in the journal of Inverse Problem and Imaging (IPI). The funding provided will be primarily allocated in support of junior researchers such as graduate students, post-docs, and entry-level faculty members, specifically to under-represented minorities and women in the STEM. The organizers will coordinate invited speakers to serve as mentors to junior researchers during the poster session and the career luncheon. The organizers also invite speakers from different countries to promote international collaborations.


Due to the blooming of 'big data' and an emerging field of data science, there is a need to bring together researchers from different disciplines to keep up with recent developments. The objectives of this workshop are (1) to facilitate discussions and foster collaborations among the participants with different backgrounds and expertise; (2) to attract new researchers to the field of data science and to offer mentoring service to junior participants in this field; and (3) to bridge the gap between the theoretical development in academia and practical applications in industry. The proposed workshop will be multidisciplinary with topics ranging from scientific computing and statistics to various applications in data science. As a result, this workshop will strengthen the relationship between mathematicians and other scientists/engineers who are interested in data science. In addition, the workshop will advance the development of computational methods, statistical theories, and tools for big data analysis. Furthermore, the workshop will build close connections between academia and industry to establish and facilitate research collaborations in a variety of data-driven applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drs. Yifei Lou (University of Texas at Dallas), Weihong Guo (Case Western Reserve University), Steve Jiang (Univeristy of Texas Southwestern Medical Center), Jing Qin (University of Kentucky), and Ming Yan (Michigan State University) organized a workshop, entitled "Recent Developments on Mathematical/Statistical Approaches in Data Science," at the University of Texas Dallas (UTD) campus on June 1-2, 2019. The workshop served the purposes of bringing together mathematicians, statisticians, computer scientists, and domain experts who are working in data science for an open dialogue on cutting-edge methodologies and computational algorithms. In addition to an extensive list of hot topics in data science, the workshop agenda featured a poster session, a luncheon for Career Panel Discussion, and a tour visit to the Univeristy of Texas Southwestern Medical Center. There were over 100 participants including 17 invited speakers, 15 faculty members, 20 postdocs, 50 graduate students. Thanks to the NSF funds, 22 graduate students received travel support to attend the workshop and gave a poster presentation. According to the exit survey, most of the participants are satisfied with the workshop.  

The workshop facilitated face to face interaction among data scientists from different disciplines and promoted communication/collaboration among mathematicians, engineers and domain scientists. Specifically, the workshop advanced the development of computational methods, statistical theories, and tools for big data analysis. In addition, the workshop also built close connections between academia and industry to establish and facilitate research collaborations in a variety of data-driven applications. Furthermore, activities including poster session and career luncheon provided novices in the STEM fields great opportunities to connect with and receive mentoring services from experts.

The workshop is of a timely fashion to advocate the UTD's data science programs and engage students within the Dallas metropolitan region to work in data science. The workshop also developed close ties between mathematics and industry, leading to positive impact on the entire mathematical sciences community in terms of promoting the STEM workforce. On the other hand, this workshop was of benefit to the data science industry in that it gives academia an opportunity to hear directly from industry leaders what the needs are in terms of workforce development, ultimately resulting in a more diverse, employable candidate pool in data science. The organizers tried all means for a diverse set of participants and inviting speakers, paying specific attentions on under-represented minorities and women. To maximize the impact of the workshop, the organizers maintain a workshop website to post presentation slides, relevant papers, and useful links to various data science programs. Furthermore, the organizers are actively soliciting original research papers from workshop participants to publish in a special issue of IPI. In the near future, the organizers will apply for financial support to host such workshops alternately to make broader impacts geographically.
